linkTarget.anchoringText: In some locations, however, where it is associated with salt collapse structures, its thickness increases to over 203 ft (70 m). Based on lithostratigraphy, the Bakken Formation can be subdivided into three members (Fig. 1); a ‘Middle’ thick (up to 144 ft (44 m) in areas of known salt dissolution) siltstone-sandstone member sandwiched between two (‘Upper’: over 29 ft (6 m); ‘Lower’: 10 – 50 ft (3-15 m)) black organic-rich marine shale members (Kresi et al., 2006; Ramakrishna et al., 2010). The thickness of the Middle Member increases towards the depositional center in northern Dakota/Montana (Ramakrishna et al., 2010).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: The stratigraphic settings of the Bakken Formation in Western Canadian Sedimentary Basin (modified after Davis (1997) and Angulo and Buatois (2012))

formatted-caption.caption-text: The stratigraphic settings of the Bakken Formation in Western Canadian Sedimentary Basin (modified after Davis (1997) and Angulo and Buatois (2012))

linkTarget.bib:
Angulo and Buatois, (2012)
S. Angulo , & L. A. Buatois , (2012). Integrating Depositional Models, Ichnology, And Sequence Stratigraphy in Reservoir Characterization: The Middle Member of the Devonian – Carboniferous Bakken Formation of Subsurface Southeastern Saskatchewan Revisited . AAPG Bulletin 96 (6): 1017 1043 .

linkTarget.anchoringText: For the study area (Fig. 2), Rock–Eval analyses indicate that most (Middle Bakken) samples are organic-lean (average TOC content: 0.3 wt. %). The measured grain density values (‘as-received’) range between 2.70 and 2.75 g/cm3 while the helium porosity values (‘as-received’) range between 8.5% and 14.1%. The measured gas permeability values increase with increasing porosity (8.5–14.1%), ranging between 5.7×10−4 and 7.3×10−2 mD. For the core plugs analyzed (‘as-received’), profile (probe) permeability values (5×10−3 – 7.3×10−2 mD) are consistently higher than pulse-decay (5.7×10−4 – 3.9×10−2 mD) permeability values. Corrected profile (probe) permeability values for ‘in-situ’ effective stress (7.3×10−4 – 2.5×10−2 mD) are, however, comparable with the pulse-decay (5.7×10−4 – 3.9×10−2 mD) permeability values.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: The study area (Bakken Formation) located in southeast Saskatchewan, Canada (modified after Davies (1997) and Smith and Bustin (2000)).

formatted-caption.caption-text: The study area (Bakken Formation) located in southeast Saskatchewan, Canada (modified after Davies (1997) and Smith and Bustin (2000)).

linkTarget.bib:
Davies, (1997)
G. R. Davies , (1997). The Triassic of the Western Canada Sedimentary Basin: Tectonic and Stratigraphic Framework, Paleogeography, Paleoclimate and Biota . Bull. Can. Petrol. Geol . 45: 434 460 .

Smith and Bustin, (2000)
M. G. Smith , & R. M. Bustin , (2000). Late Devonian And Early Mississippian Bakken And Exshaw Black Shale Source Rocks, Western Canada Sedimentary Basin: A Sequence Stratigraphic Interpretation . AAPG Bulletin 84 (7): 940 60 .

linkTarget.anchoringText: The slip-corrected profile (N2) permeability values estimated for the Bakken slabbed core at the ‘in-situ’ stress conditions range between 1.1×10−3 and 4.7×10−1 mD (Fig. 3). High resolution profile permeability provides a more accurate portrayal of the vertical heterogeneities within the reservoir (Unit A; Fig. 3) and reveals two distinct permeability trends. As indicated before (Cronkwright et al., 2016), this data can be used to identify net pay cut offs and more accurately predict the distribution of producible hydrocarbons.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Profile (probe) and pulse-decay permeability data collected for 10 meters of slabbed core and six core plugs from the Middle Bakken as used in numerical simulation. Note Unit B (Fig. 1) is not part of the stratigraphic setting in the study well.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Profile (probe) and pulse-decay permeability data collected for 10 meters of slabbed core and six core plugs from the Middle Bakken as used in numerical simulation. Note Unit B (Fig. 1) is not part of the stratigraphic setting in the study well.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Because the measurement resolution cannot be reflected in the vertical grid resolution of the simulation model, these properties were averaged and scaled up to the grid resolution (~3 ft). Knowing that the initial pressure in the Viewfield Bakken is around 2600 psi, which is well above the oil saturation (bubble point) pressure of 1480 psi, the only remaining parameter to evaluate is the initial water saturation. A combination of petrophysical analysis with lab measurement of capillary pressure resulted in the correlation depicted in Fig. 4 for rock initial water saturation versus porosity.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Relationship between porosity and initial water saturation in the Viewfield Bakken reservoir cores

formatted-caption.caption-text: Relationship between porosity and initial water saturation in the Viewfield Bakken reservoir cores

linkTarget.anchoringText: Table 2 provides a summary of vertical layer properties in the generated geomodel in which the horizontal heterogeneity was ignored. Fig. 5 displays a vertical cross section of the geo-model for porosity and water saturation values. Table 3 contains a summary of the overall properties of the entire section model.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Vertical cross section (x-z plane) of the Viewfield Bakken reservoir presenting (a) porosity and (b) initial water saturation. Two additional layers at top most are reserved for representation of the Lodgepole aquifer.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Vertical cross section (x-z plane) of the Viewfield Bakken reservoir presenting (a) porosity and (b) initial water saturation. Two additional layers at top most are reserved for representation of the Lodgepole aquifer.

linkTarget.anchoringText: To capture the physics of the fluid flow within the fracture pathways, logarithmically spaced local grid refinement is used. With this arrangement, the middle fine grid designated for the fracture plane is assigned a high permeability and the grid sizes increase on both sides of the fracture plane symmetrically. Fig. 6-a presents the top view of the reservoir with the locations of the horizontal wells and their respective hydraulic fracture planes. Fig. 6-b depicts the 3D view of reservoir from which the dip angle of the model is most obvious.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: (a) Top view of the reservoir displaying the location of individual wells and local grid refinement (LGR) used for building hydraulic fractures along the wells. (b) 3D view of the model.

formatted-caption.caption-text: (a) Top view of the reservoir displaying the location of individual wells and local grid refinement (LGR) used for building hydraulic fractures along the wells. (b) 3D view of the model.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Top view of the reservoir displaying the location of individual wells and local grid refinement (LGR) used for building hydraulic fractures along the wells

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 7 presents the final results of the history match at the field level (8 wells combined). Even under the unusual and complex arrangement of fluids in this reservoir (i.e. overlying aquifer instead of the typical configuration of bottom water), an acceptable match within a reasonable number of iterations was accomplished. Further scrutiny of Fig. 7 reveals that the simulated water production rate between days 600 and 800 (Fig. 7-b) is less than the actual production rates.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Final results of the fluid production/injection history match at field level.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Final results of the fluid production/injection history match at field level.

linkTarget.anchoringText: For relative permeability data, Corey’s correlation is utilized for both the matrix and hydraulic fractures to construct the initial curves, and thereafter, the end-points and exponents are tuned until the mismatch error becomes fairly small and stable. The final determined two-phase curves of oil-water and gas-oil systems for the matrix and the hydraulic fractures are shown in Fig. 8.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Final tuned relative permeability curves for the two-phase oil-water and gas-oil systems as obtained during the history match process (a, b) relative permeability data for the matrix; (c, d) relative permeability data for the fractures.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Final tuned relative permeability curves for the two-phase oil-water and gas-oil systems as obtained during the history match process (a, b) relative permeability data for the matrix; (c, d) relative permeability data for the fractures.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: relative permeability data for the matrix
relative permeability data for the matrix
relative permeability data for the fractures
relative permeability data for the fractures

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 9 displays the final history match results for well “B”, which is converted into a water injector after 450 days of production (Fig. 9-d). Water injection begins when the pressure near the well region has reached a low value of 1450 psi (close to oil bubble point pressure). However, the well bottom-hole pressure starts to build up immediately and rather quickly hits the maximum constraint pressure of 3,200 psi. This signifies the dominant effect of low matrix permeability on the water front advancement when the fracture density is sub-optimal in the offset producers.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Final history-match results of the fluid production/injection history of one of the wells which was converted into a water injection well after about one year (450 days) of primary production.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Final history-match results of the fluid production/injection history of one of the wells which was converted into a water injection well after about one year (450 days) of primary production.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 10-a illustrates the model-predicted long-term performance of primary recovery in this reservoir. To generate the graph, no water injection conversion is assumed to occur and all eight wells continue to act as producers. Fig. 10-b, in contrast, shows the oil production performance of the water-flood scheme if the current operation continues. The difference in recovery factor for the two scenarios is 11% (15% for primary versus 26% for waterflood). There is also a considerable difference in well productivity levels.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Forecast of long-term performance associated with (a) primary recovery and (b) the current waterflood operation in Viewfield Bakken.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Forecast of long-term performance associated with (a) primary recovery and (b) the current waterflood operation in Viewfield Bakken.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: the current waterflood operation in Viewfield Bakken

linkTarget.anchoringText: Acknowledging the fact that the fractures in this section of the Bakken are already in communication with the top aquifer, it would be instructive to investigate the situation where this does not occur. Fig. 11 compares these two cases. For primary recovery (Fig. 11-a), communication with the aquifer makes a significant difference in short-term and long-term performance, where a 5% difference in recovery factor would be observed over the first 5 years. The detrimental effect of water encroachment from the aquifer would be less on the waterflood scenario (Fig. 11-b).

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Effect of top aquifer on the forecasted long-term performance of (a) primary recovery and (b) waterflood operations in the Viewfield Bakken.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Effect of top aquifer on the forecasted long-term performance of (a) primary recovery and (b) waterflood operations in the Viewfield Bakken.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: waterflood operations in the Viewfield Bakken

linkTarget.anchoringText: In both cases, continuous injection and WAG scenarios are considered. Similar injection volumes at reservoir conditions were used in the gas flooding and waterflooding cases. A WAG ratio of one, with alternating period of 6 months was considered. Production performance of these four operations are shown in Fig. 12. Oil recovery factors are approximately 21% and 29% for continuous immiscible and miscible gas injection scenarios, respectively. These values increase to 25% and 34% when the operations switch to WAG.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Performance of different immiscible (associated gas) and miscible (CO2) gas injection schemes (a) continuous immiscible (b) WAG immiscible (c) continuous miscible (d) WAG miscible.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Performance of different immiscible (associated gas) and miscible (CO2) gas injection schemes (a) continuous immiscible (b) WAG immiscible (c) continuous miscible (d) WAG miscible.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In miscible gas flooding, maximum miscibility advantages are realized when the average reservoir pressure is maintained above the MMP. In continuous injection, after CO2 breakthrough, reservoir pressure drops below the MMP and thereafter the net CO2 utilization factor increases dramatically. As shown in Fig. 13,with an optimized WAG operation (after adjustment of its relevant parameters such as slug size and WAG ratio), it is possible to keep the average reservoir pressure above the MMP line and maximize the recovery.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Change of average reservoir pressure during CO2 continuous and WAG injection schemes and its deviation from minimum miscibility pressure in the Viewfield Bakken.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Change of average reservoir pressure during CO2 continuous and WAG injection schemes and its deviation from minimum miscibility pressure in the Viewfield Bakken.

linkTarget.anchoringText: As mentioned earlier, and depicted in Fig. 14, gravity segregation can eventually lead to the escape of injected gas (CO2) into the top aquifer. Accurate quantification of the leakage parameters (amount and rate of leakage) requires supplementary geological modelling of the Lodgepole, which is beyond the scope of this study. However, upon characterization of the leakage, modification of the operations can be considered for co-optimization of oil recovery and CO2 storage within the reservoir and the top aquifer. This will be explored in future work.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: CO2 override to the top of the Bakken Formation during the injection process. CO2 spatial distribution at the end of the injection period for (a) continuous CO2 injection (b) Water-Alternating-CO2 injection schemes. Displayed wells are the injectors.

formatted-caption.caption-text: CO2 override to the top of the Bakken Formation during the injection process. CO2 spatial distribution at the end of the injection period for (a) continuous CO2 injection (b) Water-Alternating-CO2 injection schemes. Displayed wells are the injectors.
